content.description: Start on the right facing feature. Climb up and left and finish up the mossy slab.
Jump start to an angled sloper. Traverse left to the mantel of Midnight Lightning.

What can you say about such a classic boulder problem that can possibly do it justice? First sent by Ron Kauk who worked it for over two months in 1978 with fellow hardman John Bachar, this line up the Columbia Boulder stands as a true milestone in modern rock climbing.

People have rated this from V7 to V9, and if you can't mantle it's going to feel downright impossible.

Start on the series of polished opening crimps, fire a right hand up to a good undercling crimp, move the left hand up, and then get ready to fly out to the Lightning Bolt hold with your feet kicking in the air (although if you're over 6ft. or so it can be done as a static move). The bottom moves are powerful but it's the infamous mantle that will throw most suitors back down into the dust. Trust your spotter and believe...
content.location: Right in Camp 4.  Look for the chalked lightning bolt on the rock.  You can't miss it.

content.description: Start on crimps at the bottom of the left facing corner. Go up and right to join The Robbins Problem.
Start on high crimps directly below the mantel of Midnight Lightning. Climb straight up.
content.location: Big Columbia boulder, starts right above the famous lightning bolt.

content.description: A fun problem on the backside of the Columbia Boulder. Sit start with a big left-hand sidepull and right-hand crimp sidepull. Pull powerful moves on good holds culminating with a technical mantel.
content.location: Backside of Big Columbia directly facing Little Columbia

content.description:
This is a mega classic V4 that doesn't see much traffic for some reason. It is located on the Big Columbia Boulder, just around the corner from Midnight Lightning.

Start to the right of the tree and a right facing corner (the corner is "off"). With an undercling and a big glassy foothold for your right foot, reach up and left to an angled edge. Get a high right foot above the lip and rock over to another gaston. Reach up to a jug and then climb easy terrain to the top. Although tall, this problem isn't really a highball. Once you reach the jug, it's 5.7 on big features all the way to the top. But it's a different story if the moss is wet!

To get down either downclimb the problem to the jug and drop off, or downclimb the tree to the lowest branch and drop off. If you're dropping from the tree, have someone bring a pad over or else it's kind of an ankle bruiser.

The line to the left of the mega classic Midnight Lightning was christened by Jerry Moffatt as After Midnight in 1993.  It's height will require mortals to want a toprope, yet it is technically on a boulder.  It was originally graded 7c+.

The first ropeless ascent goes to the highball master Jason Kehl in the 2000's.  If you are feeling bold and desire a ropeless ascent, bring plenty of pads.
content.protection: Toprope for the prudent or many crashpads for the insane.
content.location: Smack dab in the middle of Camp 4, left of Midnight Lightning.

content.description: Climb up Scoops to the slab top then down climb the tree
